Title: Polynomial Regression
Summary: Polynomial regression is a type of regression analysis used to model the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables. It extends linear regression by introducing polynomial terms, allowing for the modeling of non-linear relationships. In polynomial regression, the model equation is a polynomial function of the independent variable(s).

Advantages.Flexibility: Polynomial regression can capture non-linear relationships between variables, making it suitable for a wider range of data patterns.
Advantages.Accuracy: It can provide more accurate predictions when the underlying data has a non-linear structure.
Advantages.Interpretability: The coefficients of the polynomial terms can still provide insights into the relationships between variables.
Advantages.Versatility: Polynomial regression can be adapted to various degrees of complexity by adjusting the polynomial degree.

Disadvantages.Overfitting: Using a high-degree polynomial can lead to overfitting, where the model fits the training data too closely and performs poorly on new data.
Disadvantages.Model Complexity: Higher-degree polynomials can lead to complex models that are difficult to interpret and explain.
Disadvantages.Sensitivity to Outliers: Like linear regression, polynomial regression is sensitive to outliers, which can have a strong impact on the model.
Disadvantages.Extrapolation Issues: Extrapolating beyond the range of the data can be problematic, as it may lead to unreliable predictions.
